Text: You're the only one at the lounge this morning. You can't wait until The Pond reopens for morning coffee!
Beejou enters anxiously: Ah! Oh! I'm so glad you're here!
I just got an email that says Security Team Alpha detected suspicious activity using my student ID!
They're gonna lock my account if I don't verify my identity...That can't be good.
I'm me, the one and only Beejou! Could you watch my things while I go and sort this out?
The first thing we're going to look at is the header.
Next, we're going to look at the email's body.
Finally, we're going to look at the email's call to action and signature.
Is this email legit?
Trust Choice Feedback: It asks for 3 different forms of ID! Beejou heads to the library to scan her cards and you make sure her things don't move an inch while she's gone.
Distrust Choice Feedback: It wants 3 different forms of ID! You warn Beejou that this is likely a scam. She's relieved because she actually was acting a little suspicious, but only cause she wanted to surprise you with a fresh donut from Do or Donut.

Text: One of the best features of Reel Polytechnic's campus is their Pond cafeteria
You read all about it in the brochure, so you're excited to experience the Advanced Salad Bar
But you're dismayed to see it's Closed for Beautification!
What does that even mean? You check the college website to find out.
You head to the Reel Polytechnic website.
There's a blog about it! Let's read on...
Does this information look right?
Trust Choice Feedback: Sounds like you'll have to go somewhere else for Advanced Salad options, but the new features sound great.
Distrust Choice Feedback: Unfortunately the doors are locked. Looks like you better be looking for refreshments elsewhere. With features like these, this will take months to complete.

Text: You're enjoying your morning outside, daydreaming about your next visit to The Pond when it reopens.
Beejou flies in, buzzing: Did you see the posters? We're hosting a Four-Armed Basketball tournament!
We have to go! I used to play, back in the day, you know!
But there's a problem... I tried to get tickets, and my card isn't working!
Can you help me get them? Please, I don't want to miss this!
Beejou sends you the website and you open it up on your phone.
Let's take a look at this webpage
Do you buy the tickets?
Trust Choice Feedback: You check out and are promised the hand delivery. You're advised to stay on campus, otherwise they wont be able to find you, but no one ever arrives.
Distrust Choice Feedback: Beejou discovers that you can just get tickets at a table by the gym and she says she'll get you a ticket as thanks since you helped her out.

Text: You're sitting out on the grass, sipping your coffee and catching up on some reading.
Beejou calls you: Guess what! Beeyonce is coming to campus!!
I just got an email from my Beeyonce fan community with an exclusive link to buy tickets before they go on sale to the public!
I'm so excited, but also a little nervous...
It opens a link that asks for my student ID and credit card info. Do you think it's ok?
Take a look at the URL
Next, we're going to look at the webpage.
Should Beejou trust the site?
Trust Choice Feedback: You and Beejou get front row tickets. Beejou's so excited, she says she wont sleep for weeks.
Distrust Choice Feedback: Sounds worrying so you decide not to go but you can't help but wonder if concert will be one of those life changing, world altering one that everyone won't stop talking about for weeks.

Beejou enters anxiously: Ah! Oh! I'm so glad you're here!
I just got an email that says Security Team Alpha detected suspicious activity using my student ID!
They're gonna lock my account if I don't verify my identity...That can't be good.
I'm me, the one and only Beejou! Could you watch my things while I go and sort this out?
The first thing we're going to look at is the header.
Next, we're going to look at the email's body.
Finally, we're going to look at the email's call to action and signature.
Is this email legit?
Trust Choice Feedback: It asks for 3 different forms of ID! Beejou heads to the library to scan her cards and you make sure her things don't move an inch while she's gone.
Distrust Choice Feedback: It wants 3 different forms of ID! You warn Beejou that this is likely a scam. She's relieved because she actually was acting a little suspicious, but only cause she wanted to surprise you with a fresh donut from Do or Donut.

Text: You're checking your email in between power naps at the campus library.
There's an offer to access a plentitude of ebooks and textbooks!
It sounds like it could be a good deal...
First, who's sending this to me.
Let's examine the body of the email.
Finally, let's look at the offer and the signature.
Do you trust this offer?
Trust Choice Feedback: It's worrying when you crack open the dusty .pdf of 'Key Study Habits for Sucess.' It's just a single paged document listing out 3 study habits: 1. Studie with TV on. 2. Pcrorastinate until the last minnit. 3. Skip brekfast.
Distrust Choice Feedback: You report it as a phishing attempt and are thanked for your report. You worry you'll have to find 10,000's of books elsewhere, but you remember you can go to the library!

Text: You're working late in the study lounge getting some last minute things done before you go home.
You get an email asking you participate in an official college survey about student life.
You've gotten three of these this week!
I guess it could be worth it to check out.
Let's start by examining the email's header.
Next up, we'll focus on the email's message.
Finally, let's look at the email's call to action and signature.
Is this email legit?
Trust Choice Feedback: You get a sweet $10 campus store gift card, and a follow up email gives you two more to share with your friends, or get two really small mugs.
Distrust Choice Feedback: You receive an email thanking you for your vigilance in identifying phishing scams, but remember, phishing emails often request sensitive information, which Reel Polytechnic will never do!

Text: Your computer's going into red alert mode!!! There's a flashing software update message for BugBuster Antivirus!
You're unsure whether to trust it.
You call the IT service desk for help. They ask you to meet them at The Pond, where they're busy angling the phish.
One of them looks up and says: Hey there! Let's see what's going on with your computer.
Ah, yes! They mentioned this update was talked about on BugBuster's blog.
It says this update fixes a security bug. It's important to install it for your safety.
Is this update legit?
Trust Choice Feedback: You decide to trust their advice and install the update. You feel secure knowing your system is protected.
Distrust Choice Feedback: Sure, it sounds critical, but it can't actually be that critical. It can wait!

Text: You're researching at the library and get a frantic text from Beejou.
Beejou: AAA DONT CLIKC FOR FREE FLOPWERS!!!
You rush to find Beejou. She looks desperate and worried about her computer.
All I did was click a link to get free flowers and now my computer's locked!
You take Beejou to the IT service team to check over her computer. They're catching phish, but they're happy to help.
(beaver 1): Oh my, this looks like ransomware!
(beaver 2): We can try to fix it, but Beejou you need to be careful with suspicious emails.
As they work on Beejou's computer, you receive a notification. It's the same email!
(beaver 2): Since you're already here, let's walk through it together.
Hmm. Now, let's look at the body.
I can see how Beejou was fooled.
What do you think about this offer?
Trust Choice Feedback: Ahh! I know flowers are tempting but you should be wary about offers that sounds too good to be true.
Distrust Choice Feedback: That's right! If an offer sounds too good to be true, it probably is!

Text: You recently read that the Campus Cafe is trying out a new robotic coffee handler.
There's a special right now that uses AI to craft the perfect morning beverage based entirely on your mood!
But, when you get your coffee, it just doesn't taste right. It doesn't seem like it's actually yours.
You call the IT support team for help. They listen to your problem.
(beaver 1): Bring it to The Pond and we'll test it for you!
You arrive at The Pond, coffee in hand. They slap the water with their tails, looking excited.
(beaver 1): Let's take a look...
You start to suspect that they might just be aiming to get a free drink out of you.
Trust Choice Feedback: You watch as they all took a little sip each. It was kinda cute, so you didn't mind, but now you have to go get a new one. They thank you for your trouble.
Distrust Choice Feedback: They just want to drink your coffee!! Even if it's wrong, you might as well drink it. You've gotta get to the gym before it closes!
